(b) Cohesive energy (E c) of doped catalysts. (c) Formation energy (E f) of the doped catalysts, revealing thermodynamic feasibility. (d) Bader charge analysis of REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts, depicting electron transfer trends and the extent of charge redistribution upon doping of REE1. Fig. 3 PDOS of the best OER catalyst of REE1/γ-NiOOH: (a) Ce1, (b) Pr1, (c) Nd1, and (d) Tb1. Fig. 4 The CDD maps of the best OER catalysts of REE1/γ-NiOOH: (a) Ce1, (b) Pr1, (c) Nd1, and (d) Tb1. Here, the cyan color represents charge depletion, while the yellow color represents charge accumulation. The CDD plots were plotted at an iso-surface level of 0.11 using the VESTA visualization program. Fig. 5 Schematic representation of the 4e− transfer OER/ORR pathway on the REE1/γ-NiOOH surface. The forward pathway represents the OER mechanism, where water oxidation leads to oxygen evolution, while the reverse pathway depicts ORR, involving oxygen reduction to produce water. Fig. 6 Gibbs free energy profiles for the OER/ORR on REE1-doped γ-NiOOH catalysts (REE1 = (a) Ce1, (b) Pr1, (c) Nd1, and (d) Tb1) calculated at U = 0 V. These energy profiles depict the stepwise adsorption and evolution of key intermediates (*OH, *O, and *OOH), highlighting the PDS that governs the reaction kinetics in each system. The complete free energy profiles of all studied REE1 are provided in Figs. S9 and S10. Fig. 7 (a) OER and (b) ORR overpotentials of various REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts calculated by DFT method. Fig. 8 Scaling relationships between the adsorption free energies of oxygenated intermediates (ΔG *OH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OOH) for various REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts: (a) REE1 = Tb1, Yb1, and Dy1; (b) REE1 = Sc1, La1, Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, Pm1, Sm1, Gd1, Ho1, Er1, and Tm1; (c) REE1 = Y1, Eu1, and Lu1, illustrating correlations that influence catalytic performance. (d) Volcano plot of −η OER vs. (ΔG *O − ΔG *OH), identifying Tb1, Pr1, Ce1, and Nd1 systems as the most effective OER catalysts. Graphical abstract Spin polarized density functional theory (DFT) study investigates how rare-earth single atom anchored on γ-NiOOH modulates charge transfer and adsorption energetics, lowering oxygen evolution reaction/oxygen reduction reaction (OER/ORR) overpotentials and providing a mechanistic basis for designing high-performance single-atom electrocatalysts. The rational design of Ni-based catalysts is essential due to their abundance and low cost for advancing sustainable energy technologies, particularly for water splitting and fuel cells. This study employs spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) to examine the influence of anchoring rare-earth elements on the γ-NiOOH lattice surface, aiming to identify the optimal catalytic site for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Following the identification of an appropriate active site through Ni vacancy, a rare earth element (REE1) is introduced as a dopant for single-atom catalysis (SACs). The structural, thermodynamic, and catalytic characteristics of all newly designed REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts have been extensively studied. Among the newly developed catalysts, Tb1/γ-NiOOH exhibits the lowest OER overpotential of (0.36 V), while Ce1/γ-NiOOH and Pr1/γ-NiOOH also demonstrate excellent OER performance (0.51 and 0.41 V), respectively. Notably, Nd1/γ-NiOOH and Pm1/γ-NiOOH exhibit efficient ORR activity, with low overpotentials of (0.63 and 0.61 V) due to their balanced adsorption and desorption energies of intermediates. Bader charge analysis reveals strong electron donation from doped REE1 to the surface. This study identified Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, and Tb1 anchoring catalysts as highly promising for water-splitting applications. Moreover, Nd1 and Pm1 doping markedly improve ORR performance, underscoring their promise for enhanced electrochemical applications in metal-air batteries. The catalytic performance of all newly developed catalysts was further evaluated using electronic descriptors. The catalytic performance was further assessed using the volcano curve and scaling relationships for the adsorbed intermediates. This study offers an extensive theoretical foundation for designing cost-effective and high-performance REE1/γ-NiOOH electrocatalysts. Keywords Single atom catalysis (SACs) Density functional theory (DFT) Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) Oxygen reduction reaction γ-phase NiOOH 1 Introduction The continuous increase in the global energy demand and the environmental impacts of fossil fuel utilization have escalated the need for sustainable and green energy sources [1]. The fluctuating nature of renewable energy sources significantly enhances the pursuit of energy storage and conversion technology. In this regard, metal-air batteries [2,3], fuel cells [4], and water-splitting systems [5,6] are considered promising solutions for facilitating the energy transition utilizing green sources. Hydrogen (H2) has emerged as a carbon-neutral energy carrier with considerable potential to displace fossil fuels due to its high energy density and environmental compatibility [1,7]. However, the practical application of water electrolyzers is hindered by multiple factors, notably the slow reaction kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) intermediates, which lower overall catalytic performance [8]. Electrocatalysts play a crucial role in enhancing electrochemical reactions on the electrode surfaces, improving efficiency and selectivity in processes such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), OER, and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) to convert renewable energy into fuels and chemicals [9]. This transformation involves electron transfer, bond breaking, and bond formation, offering vital mechanistic insights into reaction pathways and facilitating the optimization of catalytic performance [10,11]. Significant progress has been made in understanding electrocatalytic mechanisms through Ab initio investigations. Among these, the OER and the ORR are critical due to their central roles in energy conversion technologies such as water electrolyzers, fuel cells, and rechargeable metal-air batteries. OER is a multi-electron reaction (2H2O → 4H+ + 4e− + O2) that requires the sequential transfer of four electrons and protons across the electrode/electrolyte interface [12,13]. This process entails O–H breaking and O–O bond formation on the electrode surface, necessitating efficient active sites for intermediate stabilization. The high energy barriers and sluggish kinetics of OER increase its complexity, requiring applied potentials higher than its theoretical onset potential of 1.23 V vs. standard hydrogen electrodes (SHE) to drive oxygen evolution efficiently [14]. In contrast, ORR is the cathodic half-reaction in devices such as metal-air batteries and proton-exchange membrane fuel cells. It is the reverse of OER and involves the reduction of molecular oxygen via (O2 → *OOH → *O → *OH → H2O). Similar to OER, ORR occurs through a series of intermediates; however, it is characterized by unique adsorption and desorption energetics as well as rate-determining steps. Poor reaction kinetics often limit its efficiency, requiring electrocatalysts that can facilitate rapid oxygen reduction with minimal overpotential and robust stability. Therefore, investigating the reaction energetics and intermediate transformations is crucial for the rational design of efficient ORR electrocatalysts. Computational methods such as density functional theory (DFT) have been widely employed to investigate the catalytic pathway of the designed electrocatalysts to achieve high performance [15–17]. Precious metal catalysts, notably Ir and Ru-based oxides, have considerable stability and catalytic efficiency for the OER/ORR process [18,19]. However, their industrial application is limited by high costs and limited natural sources [20]. To address these challenges, significant efforts have been focused on developing non-noble metal-based electrocatalysts [21]. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have gained considerable interest due to their high atomic efficiency and distinctive electronic environment [15,17,22,23]. SACs can be anchored onto various supports, facilitating the metal-support interaction (MSI). The catalytic activity is significantly affected by MSI, which enhances the charge transfer between metal-doped atoms and the support [24,25]. Nickel-based materials have emerged as highly promising candidates among non-noble metal electrocatalysts due to their abundance, affordability, and favorable catalytic properties in alkaline media [26]. However, most Ni-based materials undergo surface reconstruction during electrochemical reactions, particularly under alkaline conditions. This transformation often alters their original structure, converting them into active phase-local NiOOH species [27–29]. These structural changes indicate that most synthesized Ni-based catalysts function as “pre-catalysts”, with their actual activity emerging only after phase transitions. NiOOH is widely studied for electrochemical applications due to its low toxicity, affordability, and favorable chemical activity [26,30]. NiOOH has two known phase structures, β-NiOOH and γ-NiOOH. The γ-phase has attained considerable attention for its superior catalytic performance. The γ-phase features a larger interlayer spacing (over 7 Å vs. 4.85 Å in β-NiOOH), facilitated by intercalated water and cations, which enhances water and hydroxide ion transport during OER [31]. Furthermore, γ-NiOOH exhibits a higher nickel oxidation state (Ni+3.5–3.67 compared to β-NiOOH with Ni3+), enabling more efficient electron transfer and enhanced catalytic activity [32]. Its larger specific surface area and improved stability further strengthen its effectiveness as an OER catalyst [33]. Numerous studies have validated the phase transition process of Ni-based catalysts through various in-situ characterization methods, concluding that γ-NiOOH is the true catalytic phase active in the OER process [27,34,35]. Transition metal compounds are widely studied for OER catalysis due to their diverse crystal phases and tunable electronic structures [36,37]. However, their inherent activity is limited, necessitating performance enhancement strategies. Rare-earth elements (REEs), with unique 4f electron configurations, offer significant potential to improve the catalytic properties of transition metal-based materials [38,39]. REEs exhibit f-f and f-d transitions, variable coordination numbers, and reversible oxidation-state transitions, enabling dynamic surface ligand exchange [40,41] to promote charge redistribution, alter band structures, and stabilize oxygen intermediates [42]. As recently demonstrated, introducing 4f-3d orbital coupling with Gd doping to enhance the OER performance of NiFe-LDH modulates the electronic structure of adjacent Ni sites, shifts the d-band center, and optimizes the adsorption energy of *OOH intermediate [43]. This electronic perturbation also promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies, increasing active site density and accelerating charge transfer kinetics during water oxidation. Together, these effects lower the energy barrier for key OER steps, leading to superior catalytic activity compared to undoped NiFe-LDH. Nd incorporation into the NiCo2O4 spinel significantly tunes the Co redox environment, stabilizing the optimal Co oxidation states and enhancing the electronic conductivity, which together boost the OER kinetics [44]. Experimental studies also validate the feasibility of REE doping in NiOOH catalysts. In prior work, a dual-oxide lattice coupling approach was used to construct NiO/CeO2 nanowire arrays on carbon cloth, exhibiting an overpotential of just 330 mV at 50 mA cm−2 and outstanding durability in alkaline OER. CeO2 promotes oxygen vacancy formation, accelerates the NiO-to-NiOOH conversion, and forms interfacial bonds that facilitate electron injection and stabilize NiOOH, thereby enhancing intermediate adsorption and overall catalytic performance [45]. Ce-doped Ni-based metal-organic frameworks (Ni-BDC MOFs, where BDC stands for 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) were electrochemically reconstructed into NiOOH nanosheets on Ni foam, forming NiCe (10%)-MOF after cyclic voltammetry (CV) activation. This material exhibited superior OER performance compared to undoped Ni-MOF, attributed to strong Ce-Ni electronic interactions, enhanced *OH adsorption, and a reduced energy barrier for the rate-determining step, leading to improved catalytic activity and current density [46]. In NiO-CeO2-x and NiFe-LDH-CeO2-x heterojunctions, Ce-mediated generation of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 shifts the electronic structure at the interface, lowers the Ni activation energy barrier, and thus promotes γ-NiOOH formation to enhance OER performance [47]. These studies support the feasibility of REE doping in NiOOH and guide the development of more efficient electrocatalysts. Collectively, these findings highlight the redox versatility and strong metal-oxygen interactions of REEs as key levers for modulating catalytic performance in Ni-based systems. However, despite growing interest, a comprehensive understanding of how an individual REE (REE1) dopant influences the electronic environment and reaction energetics of γ-NiOOH remains lacking. In particular, a detailed understanding of how REE1 doping systematically modulates key electronic properties, such as d-band center, Bader charge, and work function, and how these parameters govern catalytic activity for OER and ORR is still underexplored. To address this knowledge gap, this study employs spin-polarized DFT simulations on γ-phase NiOOH, characterized by a two-dimensional layered structure, to elucidate the influence of single-doped REE1 on the electrocatalytic activity of OER/ORR. The 4f orbital contributions are included in the analysis and visualized through projected density of states (PDOS) plots for the most promising OER catalysts. Notably, Tb1/γ-NiOOH exhibited the highest d-band center (ε d = −2.95 eV) among all the investigated systems, indicating its enhanced ability to transfer electrons to antibonding states. This promotes easier intermediate desorption, a critical step for efficient catalytic product release. This highlights the important role of 4f orbitals under spin-polarized conditions in enhancing catalytic performance. It is demonstrated that the Ni-site in the basal plane design serves as the optimal configuration due to its decreased overpotential and enhanced adsorption of OER intermediates (*OH, *O, and *OOH). The binding, cohesive, and formation energies are calculated to assess the structural and thermodynamic stability of the newly developed catalysts. The catalytic activity is evaluated through the Gibbs free energy profiles (ΔG H * ), where energy barriers are represented by the potential-determining step (PDS). This study presents the first systematic DFT investigation of REE-doped γ-NiOOH, identifying Ce1, Pr1, and Nd1 as optimal dopants, thereby offering new insights into enhancing OER/ORR performance in non-noble-metal electrocatalysts. Fig. 1 (a–d) illustrates the various models of REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts, which have been validated for thermal stability by molecular dynamics, charge density differences, and density of states analysis. 2 Computational details Spin-polarized DFT simulations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.4.4) [48,49]. All the electronic and catalytic properties were determined using the same package, including Bader charge (q) analysis, work function (WF), d-band center (ε d), partial density of states (PDOS), and electron density difference maps (EDDs). The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was utilized to include the exchange-correlation function proposed by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) [50]. The cutoff energy was set at 400 eV using a plane-wave basis. Moreover, projector-augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials were employed to enhance computational efficiency by accurately modeling the relationship between valence and core electrons [51,52]. To minimize interlayer interactions in periodic systems, a 20 Å vacuum gap was introduced along the z-direction. The Brillouin zone sampling was performed using a 1 × 1 × 1 Γ-point mesh [53]. The relaxation of ions was allowed until the maximum force acting on ions was reduced to a threshold of 0.02 eV Å−1. Additionally, Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were conducted at 300 K to assess the thermal stability of the catalyst. It is noteworthy that DFT, rather than DFT + U, was employed as the primary computational method in this study. In the DFT + U approach, the Hubbard U parameter is an empirical, system-dependent correction typically fitted to reproduce specific experimental properties such as band gaps or oxidation energies [54,55]. However, transferable U values are not available for REE-doped γ-NiOOH surfaces. Moreover, previous studies have shown that the U value can vary significantly with local coordination environments, even for a single element such as Ce [56]. Given the diverse local geometries introduced by the 17 different REE1 dopants, applying element-specific U values would introduce non-uniform corrections and compromise the comparability of results. To ensure internal consistency and avoid arbitrary bias, all calculations were conducted at the standard PBE level. Although DFT + U can shift absolute adsorption energies, prior work has demonstrated that catalytic trends and scaling relationships remain largely unaffected [55], supporting the use of uniform PBE for reliable screening across the REE1 series. The AIMD simulations employed the 4 × 4 × 1 supercell size with vacuum space in the z-direction to avoid interlayer interactions. The system consists of 56 atoms; the total simulation was adjusted to 3000 steps at 3 ps. The Nosé-Hoover thermostat was employed under the NVT ensemble (constant Number of particles, Volume, and Temperature) to control the system temperature. The radial distribution function (RDF) of various atomic pairs after the AIMD simulation is computed as illustrated in Fig. S1. The RDFs for Ni–O, O–H, and Ni–Ni exhibit sharp peaks at expected bonding distances, reflecting the retained short-range order in the γ-NiOOH structure. Notably, O–Tb and Ni–Tb RDFs display clear first-neighbor peaks at 2.0–3.0 Å, indicating stable coordination of the Tb dopant without inducing lattice disruption. The flat Tb–Tb RDF further confirms that the dopant remains isolated and does not cluster, preserving its nature as a single-atom dopant. The γ-NiOOH structure facilitates the doping of REE1 SACs at the best anchored sites. After a detailed investigation, a single REE1 atom was doped at the most optimal Ni-vacancy site. This computational methodology provides a detailed understanding of the catalytic and structural properties that govern the performance of these materials in OER. The binding energy (E b) was calculated to evaluate the stability of REE1 doping on γ-NiOOH. (1) E b = E R E E 1 / γ - N i O O H - E R E E 1 - E γ - N i O O H where E REE1/γ-NiOOH is the total energy of the REE1-doped γ-NiOOH structure, E γ-NiOOH is the energy of the defective γ-NiOOH surface, and E REE1 is the energy of the pure REE1 atom. More negative (E b ) values indicate stronger adsorption and enhanced thermodynamic stability [57]. The cohesive energy (E c) of the REE1-doped γ-NiOOH surface was evaluated as (2) E c = E S - ( n O E O + n N i E N i + n H E H + n R E E 1 E R E E 1 ) / n where E S is the total electronic energy of the catalyst with doped REE1, while n O E O, n H E H, n Ni E Ni, and n REE1 E REE1 are the contributions from the reference electronic energies of oxygen (O), hydrogen (H), nickel (Ni), and doped rare earth metals (REE1), respectively. The cohesive energy per atom (E n) is calculated as (3) E n = E / n where n is the total number of atoms of the catalyst. The formation energy (E f) was computed to determine the thermodynamic favorability of REE1 doping on the γ-NiOOH surface and can be given (4) E f = [ E R E E 1 / γ - N i O O H - E γ - N i O O H - E R E E 1 ] / N where N is the total number of contributing atoms. A more negative E f suggests a spontaneous and thermodynamically favorable doping process [58]. The comprehensive computational details for the OER and ORR can be found in the Supporting Information (SI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Active site identification and structural stability of REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts The catalytic performance of γ-NiOOH was evaluated by comparing various distinct nickel sites. As shown in the free energy profiles in Fig. S2(a), Ni-Site-1 and Ni-Site-2 exhibit the two most optimal sites for OER. Both sites follow the same OER mechanism, with the sequential adsorption of *OH, *O, and *OOH intermediates, with the release of the final product O2. The calculated overpotential (η OER) for the Ni-Site-1 is 1.12 V, greater than the 1.09 V for the Ni-Site-2, indicating that both sites exhibit comparable catalytic activity. However, the slightly reduced η OER at Ni-Site-2 can be attributed to more efficient stabilization of the *O intermediate, facilitating the transition to *OOH. The close proximity in overpotential values between the two nickel sites suggests that γ-NiOOH provides a robust and flexible framework for OER catalysis. Both sites demonstrate sufficient stability to drive OER, implying that the overall structure of γ-NiOOH is well-suited for maintaining high catalytic performance, irrespective of minor variations in site selection. The effect of REE1 doping on γ-NiOOH was explored by comparing multiple sites for Ce doping on the γ-NiOOH surface; three of the most optimal sites for OER (Ce-Site-1, Ce-Site-2, and Ce-Site-3) are presented in Fig. S2(d). The free energy profiles presented in Fig. S2(c) show clear differences in the energy of reaction intermediates at each site, revealing the significant impact of dopant positioning on OER performance. Among the three sites, Ce-Site-1 shows the lowest overpotential (η OER = 0.51 V), with a PDS of 1.74 eV during the second step (OH* → O*). This indicates that Ce-Site-1 provides an optimal environment for oxygen intermediate stabilization, improving the catalytic efficiency compared to the pure γ-NiOOH sites. Ce-Site-2 and Ce-Site-3 show higher PDS values of 2.00 and 2.13 eV, respectively, suggesting reduced catalytic performance due to less favorable interactions with *O and *OOH intermediates. The higher energy barriers at these sites likely arise from variations in Ce coordination and local charge distribution, which weaken the adsorption strength of the intermediates. Thus, Ce-Site-1 is the optimal site for Ce doping on γ-NiOOH and will be used for doping all REE1 atoms to enable a consistent comparison. As evident from the improved overpotential and reaction energetics with doping, REE1 doping is expected to significantly enhance the catalytic activity of γ-NiOOH for OER. The structural stability of all developed catalysts is examined by investigating the binding energy (E b), cohesive energy (E c), and formation energy (E f). The E b ensures the strength of the interaction between the anchored REE1 and the catalyst substrate (γ-NiOOH) to verify the stability of the catalysts. E b is an essential descriptor for the screening and design of SACs regarding their applicability, which facilitates the optimization of catalysts for efficient and enduring catalytic performance. The elevated E b values signify that the catalytic sites maintain contact with the adsorbate, whereas the diminished E b values show the repulsive interaction between the adsorbate and the catalyst surface, which is unfavorable for achieving stable intermediate energy. Sabatier’s principle posits that the interaction intensity must be equilibrated to facilitate the adsorption and desorption processes on the catalyst surface. All engineered catalysts exhibit negative E b values, indicating their potential thermodynamic stability. The E b value observed in Dy1/γ-NiOOH is −18.30 eV, which is abnormal compared to all other investigated catalysts. The highest binding energies were observed for Ce1/γ-NiOOH (E b = −5.83 eV) and Tb1/γ-NiOOH (E b = −5.32 eV), while the lowest value was measured for Eu1/γ-NiOOH (E b = −0.01 eV) as illustrated Fig. 2 (a). The intrinsic activity of our designed SACs can be evaluated by finding the E c. An excellent catalyst must have the ability to withstand harsh conditions to support the long-term stability of the catalyst. The higher E c implies that atoms are more tightly bound in the bulk state. Sc1/γ-NiOOH has an E c value of −6.71 eV, indicating its ability to make strong binding, while the Y1/γ-NiOOH (E c = −5.07 eV) demonstrates the weakest value, which does not support the long-term stability of the catalysts (Fig. 2b). The E c values of the lanthanide series dopants often fall within the range from −5.60 to −5.90 eV, indicating that the bulk stabilities are consistent throughout the series. Ensuring excellent OER performance during catalytic processes requires a harmonized cohesive energy and powerful adherence to the host surface to preserve isolated dopant distribution. To assess the thermodynamic stability of the proposed catalysts, their formation energy was calculated (Fig. 2c), and the lowest value for Yb1/γ-NiOOH (E f = −0.14 eV) confirms the ability to keep dopants on the catalytic surface. On the other hand, the highest E f exhibited by Eu1/γ-NiOOH (E f = +5.83 eV) depicts that doping Eu is not suitable and leads to thermodynamically unfavorable conditions during OER. Overall, the lower E f supports the anchoring of metals and enhances the durability of the catalyst. All energy values were calculated using Eqs. (1)–(4). The corresponding results, including E b, E c, E f, and the total energy of the catalyst systems, are summarized in Table S1. 3.2 Electronic descriptors for REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts The electronic properties are significant for understanding the reaction kinetics, redistribution of electrons, and catalytic activity of designed catalysts. For the examined catalysts, the d-band center (ε d), Bader charge (q), work function (WF), and partial density of states (PDOS) were computed. 3.2.1 d-band center (εd) The ε d describes the average contribution of the d-orbitals from the PDOS, which is widely used to understand the nature of the catalytic behavior of anchored metals over the catalyst surface. The OER catalytic performance is strongly influenced by the ability of d-orbital electrons to facilitate the adsorption and desorption of reaction intermediates at specific active sites. The ε d describes the dopants inducing either the downward shift (filling of anti-bonding states) or upward shift (more electrons present in bonding state), leading to desorption and adsorption, respectively [59]. The upward shift means that ε d is present near the Fermi energy level (E − E F = 0), while the downward shift denotes the weaker adsorption of catalytic intermediates over the catalyst surface. An excessive downward shift (more negative) corresponds to weaker desorption, which may hinder the formation of the final product. In our case, the lowest ε d exhibited by Sc1/γ-NiOOH (ε d = −1.98 eV) suggests a stronger interaction of the anchored Sc metal atom. In contrast, the highest value demonstrated by Yb1/γ-NiOOH (ε d = −2.55 eV) represents the weak adsorption of intermediates, which may affect the catalytic activity. Among the designed catalysts, Sc1/γ-NiOOH and Lu1/γ-NiOOH (ε d = −2.2 eV) exhibit strong adsorption strength, which is favorable for intermediate binding but may also indicate potential over-binding, as inferred from the overall OER intermediate energies. The catalysts Pr1, Nd1, Ce1, Dy1, Er1, and Tb1 show the balanced adsorption of intermediates, potentially making them excellent OER catalysts at the optimum ε d. The measured values of ε d can be found in Table S2. 3.2.2 Bader charge (q) The Bader charge analysis provides insight into the charge transfer between the anchored REE1 and the catalyst surface. The net charge can be described with positive +q and negative −q, which represents the overall contribution of each metal atom. When the anchored atom has a positive +q, it implies the loss of electrons, while the negative charge −q indicates the excess of electrons. The color codes have been used to differentiate the areas of high and low electron-dense regions over the catalyst surface [60]. In our study, the cyan color in charge density difference maps represents the loss of electrons, while the yellow represents the accumulation of electron density. Commonly, the anchored metals with low electronegativity show the loss of electrons. Here, it is observed that Sc1/γ-NiOOH (q = 2.48 e) and Ce1/γ-NiOOH (q = 2.24 e) exhibit the highest charge transfer due to strong electron donation to nearby atoms to enable the coordination environment via redistribution of electrons. The lower q present in the range of 1.95–2.05 e shows weaker electron transfer due to less redistribution of the electronic cloud. The catalyst with moderate charge transfers is present in the range of 2.05–2.15 e as presented in Fig. 2(d). These are the individual q of simply anchored REE1 over the catalyst surface; we will study the best OER catalyst in more detail by examining the ε d and q of each intermediate. 3.2.3 Work-function ( Φ ) The work function describes the energy required to transfer an electron from the solid surface to the vacuum. The lower Φ facilitates the electron transfer, which leads to the enhanced electrocatalytic performance [61–63]. In our case, Sc1/γ-NiOOH exhibits the highest work function ( Φ = 5.58 eV), indicating that electron removal from the surface is more difficult. This, in turn, hinders electron redistribution and ultimately reduces the catalytic activity of the material. The catalysts with lower Φ are Yb1, Tb1, Nd1, Ce1, and Pr1, while the higher Φ was observed for the catalysts Sc1, Y1, and Lu1. The most promising Φ exhibited by Yb1/γ-NiOOH ( Φ = 5.22 eV) and Tb1/γ-NiOOH ( Φ = 5.26 eV) might face fewer restrictions during the catalytic reactions. The DFT estimated values of Φ of all newly developed catalysts are presented in Table S2. Thus, optimizing the Φ can directly enhance the electron transfer, improving catalytic activity. Different methods can be utilized, like doping, defect, strain, and vacancy effect, which not only improve the Φ but are also highly effective in improving the OER performance of the catalyst. 3.2.4 Density of states (DOS) analysis The DOS represents the number of electronic states present at each energy level to occupy the electrons. For the best-performing OER catalysts, the PDOS profiles (Fig. 3 ) show notable d-orbital states near the Fermi level, suggesting strong intermediate interaction and catalytic activity. Remaining profiles are shown in Figs. S3 and S4. All the DOS plots were drawn at the E − E F = 0. The catalytic performance of the catalyst relies on how the O-2p and REE1-5d electrons interact with each other during the interaction at E F. The higher peaks of elements show the rapid electron transfer near the E F. In DOS plots, the adsorption strength of catalysts is depicted by ε d. The individual contributions of the d-orbitals for the most active OER catalyst were analyzed to visualize how the peaks near the Fermi level evolve, highlighting their role in enhancing catalytic activity. The corresponding d-orbital-resolved DOS is presented in Fig. S5. The 4f orbital contributions were visualized through PDOS plots for the most promising OER catalysts. Notably, Tb1/γ-NiOOH exhibited the highest d-band center (ε d = −2.95 eV) among all investigated systems, indicating its enhanced ability to transfer electrons to anti-bonding states, facilitating easier desorption. This highlights the important role of 4f orbitals under spin-polarized conditions in enhancing catalytic performance. The PDOS of the best OER catalysts can be found in Fig. S6. The adsorption strength and electron availability of catalysts can be estimated by combining the DOS and ε d. Nørskov et al. demonstrated that superior catalytic activity can be achieved by optimizing the DOS and ε d of intermediates [61]. The charge density difference (CDD) maps of all designed catalysts are also constructed to visualize the redistribution of electron density upon adsorption of REE1 over the surface of the catalyst. The CDD plots of the optimal catalyst are depicted in Fig. 4 , whereas those for the other catalysts are shown in Figs. S7 and S8. These maps can be obtained by subtracting isolated surface and adsorbate electron densities from the combined systems. The cyan color depicts the loss of electrons, mainly observed over the anchored REE1, while the yellow spots are around anchored REE1 to accept the electrons. The adopted color schemes clearly show the charge transfer from adsorbate to substrate. 3.3 OER/ORR catalytic activity of REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts The comprehensive OER/ORR performance is evaluated by calculating the final reaction-free energy of the four primary steps (ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3, and ΔG 4) based on the adsorption-free energies of intermediates (OH*, O*, and OOH*). The catalytic activity of REE1-doped γ-NiOOH catalysts for the OER and ORR was systematically investigated using Nørskov’s computational hydrogen electrode framework [64]. The OER mechanism involves four sequential proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) steps presented in Fig. 5 and Eqs. (a)–(d) in the SI: (i) dissociation of H2O into *OH and H+, (ii) conversion of *OH to *O with the release of H+, (iii) reaction of *O with H2O to form *OOH and H+, and (iv) decomposition of *OOH, releasing O2 and a H+. Conversely, the ORR pathway follows the reverse sequence, initiating with O2 adsorption and proceeding through *OOH and *O intermediates to form H2O. The overall OER and ORR performance of all catalysts was analyzed, especially focusing on their Gibbs free energy (ΔG) across four elementary reaction steps. The computed ΔG values, illustrated in Figs. S9 and S10, reveal the binding interactions between REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts and key oxygenated intermediates (*OH, *O, and *OOH). The Gibbs free energy differences further identify the PDS and quantify the overpotential η for each catalyst. By doping REE1 over the catalytic site, the electronic structure and surface reactivity of γ-NiOOH were modulated, influencing dopant-specific interactions with *OH, *O, and *OOH intermediates. For an ideal OER electrocatalyst, the energy barrier between two consecutive reaction steps should be precisely 1.23 eV, ensuring a zero overpotential [17]. Back et al. suggest that the optimal values of various reaction coordinates for ideal OER catalytic activity are 1.23 eV for ΔG *OH, 2.46 eV for ΔG *O, and 3.69 eV for ΔG *OOH [65]. However, real catalysts deviate from this ideal scenario, where unequal energy barriers across elementary steps lead to varying overpotentials, ultimately influencing catalytic efficiency [66]. As shown in Figs. S9 and S10, ΔG *OH values associated with the initial PCET step for REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts (REE1 = Sc1, Y1, La1, Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, Pm1, Sm1, Eu1, Gd1, Tb1, Ho1, Er1, Tm1, Yb1, and Lu1) range from 1.34 to 2.67 eV except for Dy1/γ-NiOOH. These values indicate varying degrees of interaction strength between the REE1 dopants and the hydroxyl (*OH) intermediate. Lower values indicate a stronger binding affinity, facilitating the initial adsorption step, whereas higher values indicate weaker interactions. For catalysts with REE1 = Tb1, Dy1, and Yb1, the initial PCET step acts as the PDS. Dy1/γ-NiOOH shows an exceptionally high ΔG *OH value of 5.53 eV, indicating weak *OH adsorption, resulting in a large OER overpotential of 4.30 V. While Tb1/γ-NiOOH exhibits a low ΔG *OH value of 1.59 eV and an outstanding overpotential of 0.36 V (Fig. 6 ). This suggests that moderate *OH binding strength of Tb facilitates efficient initial water dissociation, contributing to its superior OER performance. The REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts (REE1 = Sc1, La1, Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, Pm1, Sm1, Gd1, Ho1, Er1, and Tm1) have the second PCET step, which turns *OH into the *O radical, as the PDS. The Gibbs free energy profiles for these catalysts are also presented in Figs. S9 and S10. ΔG *O values for these REE1/γ-NiOOH-based catalysts range from 3.04 to 4.88 eV, with Ce1/γ-NiOOH (3.05 eV) and Pr1/γ-NiOOH (3.09 eV) demonstrating the most favorable energetics for *O generation. This intermediate step is critical for the oxygen evolution mechanism, as a balanced interaction with *O ensures that the catalyst remains active without being poisoned by excessively strong binding, which would hinder the desorption of reaction intermediates. These catalysts show considerably low overpotentials, with Ce1 (0.51 V) and Pr1 (0.42 V), comparable with well-known catalysts like MoC2 (0.45 V) [67] and IrO2 (0.56 V) [68]. The Gibbs free energy profiles for Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, and Tb1 systems are presented in Fig. 6(a–d), while for all the other catalysts, free energy profiles are presented in Figs. S9 and S10. The balanced *O adsorption in Ce1-doped and Pr1-doped systems ensures neither over-stabilization (which poisons active sites) nor under-stabilization (which slows intermediate conversion), aligning with the Sabatier principle for optimal catalysis [69]. Moreover, it is observed that for the catalysts with REE1 = Y1, Eu1, and Lu1, the third PCET step (*OOH formation) is the PDS with ΔG 3 values ranging from 2.16 to 3.11 eV. This indicates that the REE1 dopants exhibit strong bonding interactions with *O at the second PCET step, which makes the *OOH formation at the third step and the subsequent O2 desorption at the fourth step more energy-intensive, ultimately slowing down the reaction kinetics and increasing the overpotential. The bond length of adsorbed intermediates was also considered when calculating the interaction strength. The bond length between REE1 and O ranges from 2.06 to 2.18 Å. La1, Ce1, Pr1, Sm1, and Gd1 have a longer bond length than Sc1, and Y1, which is shorter. Our measured values for O–H adsorption on the catalyst surface indicate consistent bonding. Our best catalyst, Tb1/γ-NiOOH, exhibits uniform bond length throughout all three intermediates. Table S3 shows the bond lengths for all intermediates. Based on the calculated OER overpotentials values of catalysts (REE1 = Sc1 (1.34 V), Y1 (0.93 V), La1 (1.49 V), Ce1 (0.51 V), Pr1 (0.41 V), Nd1 (0.69 V), Pm1 (0.80 V), Sm1 (0.99 V), Eu1 (0.95 V), Gd1 (1.25 V), Tb1 (0.36 V), Dy1 (4.29 V), Ho1 (1.80 V), Er1 (1.49 V), Tm1 (1.27 V), Yb1 (1.44 V), and Lu1 (1.88 V)), as presented in Table S4 a significant energy is required for Sc1, Y1, La1, Sm1, Eu1, Gd1, Dy1, Ho1, Er1, Tm1, Yb1, and Lu1 systems to catalyze the OER effectively, making these systems unsuitable for OER as well as ORR catalytic activity. Notably, catalysts containing Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, and Tb1 dopants demonstrate exceptional catalytic performance for the OER, with overpotentials of 0.51, 0.41, 0.69, and 0.36 V, respectively. Their optimal ΔG values for *OH, *O, and *OOH adsorption facilitate smooth progression through key reaction steps, ensuring minimal energy barriers through the OER pathway. Tb1/γ-NiOOH, with the lowest overpotential ( η OER = 0.36 V), demonstrates the most favorable energetics, followed closely by Pr1-doped and Ce1-doped systems, which also show balanced intermediate adsorption and high catalytic efficiency. The balanced adsorption energetics of Tb1, Pr1, and Ce1 doped systems align with the Sabatier principle, positioning them as promising alternatives to costly noble-metal catalysts. The overpotentials of these catalysts are comparable to those of widely studied benchmark catalysts such as IrO2 (0.56 V) [68], MoC2 (0.45 V) [67], RuO2 (0.37 V) [70], and Pt/Ni-N2C2 (0.27/0.40 V) [70], indicating their significant potential for OER electrocatalysis. In addition, the pH effect for the best OER catalyst (Tb1/γ-NiOOH) was incorporated in this study. It is observed that while the energies of the intermediates changed slightly, the overall OER overpotential remained unchanged across different pH values. This indicates that Tb1/γ-NiOOH maintains stability under a range of electrochemical conditions. The Gibbs free energy profile at various pH ranges for the Tb1/γ-NiOOH can be found in Fig. S11. For comparison, DFT + U calculations were performed for the best-performing OER catalyst (e.g., Tb1/γ-NiOOH) using the DFT with U values applied to Ni (U = 5.5 eV) and the REE1 dopant Tb = 4.5 eV, consistent with the literature. As shown in Fig. S12, DFT + U slightly alters the absolute adsorption energies by ∼0.1–0.2 eV, the overall trends in intermediate energetics, overpotential, and the catalytic ranking remaining nearly unchanged relative to standard PBE calculations. Fig. S12 also summarizes the Gibbs free energy profile for the best OER catalysts calculated by the DFT + U method. It was found that Tb1/γ-NiOOH exhibits the lowest PDS value of 1.63 eV with η OER = 0.38 V using the DFT + U method, indicating reduced OER activity compared to the best OER candidates identified with standard PBE calculations. Nevertheless, our best OER catalyst retains a relatively low overpotential in both approaches, confirming its robustness. The ORR activity of REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts exhibits distinct trends based on the Gibbs free energy profiles in Figs. S9 and S10. It was observed that the best ORR activity is exhibited by the Pm1/γ-NiOOH catalyst at η OER = 0.61 V due to balanced adsorption strength of the intermediate at O* → OOH* as shown in Fig. S9. The calculated ORR overpotentials reveal that catalysts containing Sc1 (1.30 V), Y1 (1.09 V), La1 (1.27 V), Sm1 (1.25 V), Eu1 (1.35 V), Gd1 (1.09 V), Dy1 (1.68 V), Ho1 (3.77 V), Er1 (1.07 V), Yb1 (2.22 V), and Lu1 (1.25 V) require substantial energy input due to their strong binding affinity with intermediates, which elevates energy barriers during intermediates steps. Their significantly higher overpotentials compared to the well-known Pt catalyst (0.45 V) [71] indicate poor ORR efficiency. The excessive binding strength of intermediates disrupts the optimal adsorption-desorption balance, impeding the reduction of O2 and hindering the activation process, ultimately leading to sluggish reaction kinetics. Among the REE1-doped γ-NiOOH catalysts, Nd1 (0.62 V) and Pm1 (0.61 V) demonstrate the most efficient ORR kinetics. Their well-balanced ΔG values for intermediates result in efficient catalytic activity. Tb1, Ce1, and Pr1 systems also exhibit moderate ORR performance, with a similar overpotential value of 0.96 V. These REEs maintain favorable ΔG values across the key reaction steps, allowing for smooth electron and proton transfers, contributing to their relatively low energy requirements for ORR. Accordingly, Nd1, Pm1, Tb1, Ce1, and Pr1 emerge as promising ORR catalysts with well-optimized energy profiles and low to moderate overpotentials. Their comparative OER and ORR performances are summarized in Fig. 7 , highlighting the activity trends across the REE1/γ-NiOOH series. Furthermore, to highlight the significance of rare-earth-doped γ-NiOOH compared to simple NiOOH-based catalysts, recent studies were compiled in Table S5, which summarizes how OER overpotentials vary with simple doping and rare-earth metal incorporation. The electrochemical stability of the doped catalysts under reductive and oxidative conditions is critical to their bifunctional catalytic application. Therefore, Pourbaix diagrams of the two best-performing REE-doped catalysts, Ce1/γ-NiOOH and Tb1/γ-NiOOH, were calculated to assess the dissolution tendency of the dopant species and their phase transitions across varying pH and potential conditions, as shown in Fig. S13. The Pourbaix diagram of Ce1/γ-NiOOH demonstrates excellent electrochemical stability across both ORR and OER regimes in Fig. S13(a). Under low reducing potentials, the surface remains in a clean, adsorbate-free (*) state. A narrow *OH domain emerges at low pH in the OER region, followed by a small *OOH region representing surface-bound intermediates without structural degradation. At higher potentials, CeO2(s) becomes the stable bulk phase, reflecting complete lattice oxidation. Overall, Ce1 remains in insoluble solid phases across operational voltages, confirming its stability and retention in γ-NiOOH. Likewise, Tb1/γ-NiOOH exhibits an excellent thermodynamic stability across the entire ORR potential range, with the surface remaining in the clean, undisturbed state, as shown in Fig. S13(b). The formation of aqueous Tb3+ is only favored under extreme oxidizing potential (V SHE > 1.8 V) and a strongly acidic environment. These results confirm that both Ce1 and Tb1 dopants remain securely embedded within the γ-NiOOH matrix under practical electrochemical conditions, supporting their durability and suitability for OER/ORR catalysis. 3.4 Scaling relationships and volcano curve The catalytic activity of REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts for OER and ORR was further investigated utilizing the adsorption free energies of oxygenated intermediates (ΔG *OH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OOH) as descriptors [15,23]. This descriptor-based technique can effectively be employed for selecting the optimal OER/ORR catalysts if the adsorption free energies of the intermediates have a correlation [14]. Unlike transition-metal-based systems, where 3d, 4d, and 5d metals often conform to unified scaling behavior, the REE1/γ-NiOOH systems in this study exhibit various scaling behaviors due to variations in f-orbital participation and charge transfer characteristics. These differences disrupt collective scaling relations by altering the stabilization of oxygenated intermediates. The catalysts are grouped by their rate-determining steps (RDS) to explicitly highlight how the dopant-induced effects shift the energetics of specific OER steps. This revealed clear linear scaling within each group, highlighting consistent adsorption behavior and mechanistic similarity across subsets. Fig. 8 (a–c) represents the resulting scaling relationships between the intermediates for different REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts. For REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts having the PDS at ΔG 1, there is a strong correlation between ΔG *O and ΔG *OH as indicated by the scaling relation in Fig. 8(a) (ΔG *O = 0.5477ΔG *OH + 2.4645), with a coefficient of determination of (R 2 = 0.9507). For REE1-doped catalysts where the PDS occurs at ΔG 2, a linear scaling relation is observed between ΔG *OH and ΔG *O (ΔG *O = 1.9362ΔG *OH + 0.7126, R 2 = 0.6428). Several points deviating from the fitted relation between ΔG *OH and ΔG *O, which can be attributed to differences in 4f-electron configurations across the REE1 series, influencing the charge delocalization and lattice relaxation (Fig. 8b). This behavior is further supported by the d-band center shifts (Table S2), indicating modifications in the local environment of the adsorption sites. Additionally, Y1-, Lu1-, and Eu1-doped γ-NiOOH catalysts demonstrate a linear correlation between ΔG *OOH and ΔG *OH as indicated by ΔG *OOH = 0.9491ΔG *OH + 3.2176 (R 2 = 0.9036) in Fig. 8(c). The difference (ΔG *O − ΔG *OH) can be utilized as a descriptor for evaluating the OER performance [15,23]. Therefore, a volcano curve relationship between the difference (ΔG *O − ΔG *OH) and the negative OER overpotential is constructed to further evaluate OER performance, as presented in Fig. 8(d). It is observed that Tb1/γ-NiOOH, Pr1/γ-NiOOH, Ce1/γ-NiOOH, and Nd1/γ-NiOOH catalysts exhibit the lowest η OER values of 0.36, 0.41, 0.51, and 0.69 V, respectively, and present at the apex of the curve. However, a few systems, such as Dy1 and Yb1, exhibit extreme descriptors likely due to solvation or sluggish kinetic environment not fully captured by gas-phase energies of intermediates or the onset of lattice oxygen participation, which alters the standard descriptor-based activity trends. Overall, Tb1/γ-NiOOH, Pr1/γ-NiOOH, Ce1/γ-NiOOH, and Nd1/γ-NiOOH emerge as the most promising OER catalysts. 4 Conclusions A comprehensive theoretical calculation has been performed to evaluate the OER/ORR process of single-atom catalysts of REE1 (Sc1, Y1, La1, Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, Pm1, Sm1, Eu1, Gd1, Tb1, Dy1, Ho1, Er1, Tm1, Yb1, and Lu1) on γ-NiOOH substrate. Spin-polarized DFT calculation has been applied to assess the structural stability, thermodynamic and electronic characteristics, and catalytic performance of the newly developed REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts. Most of the REE1-doped γ-NiOOH catalysts exhibit strong metal-oxygen interactions and robust structural stability. Typically, Ce1/γ-NiOOH and Yb1/γ-NiOOH achieve the highest binding energies (−5.83 eV), whereas Tb1 (−5.32 eV) and Sc1 (−4.95 eV) also show significantly favorable adsorption. Additionally, Bader charge analysis reveals considerable electron transfer (1.95–2.48 |e|), indicating strong metal-surface interactions. For OER performance, Ce1 (η OER = 0.51 V), Pr1 (η OER = 0.41 V), Nd1 (η OER = 0.69 V), and Tb1 (η OER = 0.36 V) systems emerge as the best OER catalysts based on the energetics of their stable intermediates. Notably, Tb1-doped γ-NiOOH yields the lowest overpotential at (η OER = 0.36 V). The obtained lowered overpotential has been further verified by electronic descriptors and scaling relationships. By contrast, Ce1 (η OER = 0.51 V) and Pr1 (η OER = 0.41 V) catalysts show well-balanced adsorption energies, enabling OER performance comparable to benchmark catalysts such as IrO2 and MoC2. For ORR, Nd1 (η ORR = 0.63 V) and Pm1 (η ORR = 0.61 V) systems exhibit the most favorable overpotentials, with Tb1, Ce1, and Pr1 systems also demonstrating moderate ORR activity. These trends are additionally verified by linear scaling relationships and a volcano plot, which designates Tb1, Ce1, Pr1, and Nd1 as nearly ideal dopants over the surface. Our theoretical findings can provide a valuable framework for experimentalists in developing highly efficient, cost-effective electrocatalysts with improved OER activity. coredata.dc:description: The rational design of Ni-based catalysts is essential due to their abundance and low cost for advancing sustainable energy technologies, particularly for water splitting and fuel cells. This study employs spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) to examine the influence of anchoring rare-earth elements on the γ-NiOOH lattice surface, aiming to identify the optimal catalytic site for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Following the identification of an appropriate active site through Ni vacancy, a rare earth element (REE1) is introduced as a dopant for single-atom catalysis (SACs). The structural, thermodynamic, and catalytic characteristics of all newly designed REE1/γ-NiOOH catalysts have been extensively studied. Among the newly developed catalysts, Tb1/γ-NiOOH exhibits the lowest OER overpotential of (0.36 V), while Ce1/γ-NiOOH and Pr1/γ-NiOOH also demonstrate excellent OER performance (0.51 and 0.41 V), respectively. Notably, Nd1/γ-NiOOH and Pm1/γ-NiOOH exhibit efficient ORR activity, with low overpotentials of (0.63 and 0.61 V) due to their balanced adsorption and desorption energies of intermediates. Bader charge analysis reveals strong electron donation from doped REE1 to the surface. This study identified Ce1, Pr1, Nd1, and Tb1 anchoring catalysts as highly promising for water-splitting applications. Moreover, Nd1 and Pm1 doping markedly improve ORR performance, underscoring their promise for enhanced electrochemical applications in metal-air batteries. The catalytic performance of all newly developed catalysts was further evaluated using electronic descriptors. The catalytic performance was further assessed using the volcano curve and scaling relationships for the adsorbed intermediates. This study offers an extensive theoretical foundation for designing cost-effective and high-performance REE1/γ-NiOOH electrocatalysts.
